awd_titl_txt: IRES Track I: Sensors and Machine Learning for Solar Power Monitoring and Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This program promotes international multidisciplinary research opportunities for U.S. students at the overlap of sustainability, power systems and signal processing with the aim of improving efficiency in PV power generation. Algorithms for shading prediction and fault optimization will advance the state of the art in remote solar array management.  Training students in machine learning, vision and data processing for energy systems is unique and requires an integrative approach.  IRES participants will be immersed in producing and understanding solar analytics and creating algorithms and software to control solar arrays. The IRES program will engage faculty researchers from the Arizona State University SenSIP center and from the University of Cyprus KIOS Center in solar energy research. Programs and workshops will be established so that IRES participants are trained in machine learning for energy systems and present their research results in international settings. Weekly presentations at the international site and guidance by international mentors will enrich the cohort research experience. Embedding students in the KIOS center research labs funded by large European Union (EU) grants will provide knowledge on EU and international research practices, energy standards and policies. Students will spend six summer weeks at the University of Cyprus KIOS center to improve their research skills and elevate their cultural competencies.  This international research endeavor will energize students to innovate and disseminate results globally. 

 Solar energy or photovoltaic (PV) arrays encounter loss of efficiency under conditions of shading, panel faults and temperature variations.  In fact, shading, weather patterns, soiling, and temperature reduce power output considerably. For example, a malfunction of one panel will cause an entire PV string to fail.  To minimize inefficiencies, individual panel current-voltage (I-V) measurements, weather information, and imaging data are essential. Controlling the power output is possible through solar panel matrix switching and optimization (i.e., changing certain array connections from series to parallel using actuators). Matrix switching using programmable relays allows for different interconnection options. The research goal is to optimize PV array systems by: a) exploiting the measured I-V patterns to detect faults using machine learning, b) employing advanced imaging and vision techniques to predict shading, c)  using temperature, irradiance  and weather data to elevate PV efficiency, and d) include smart grid interfaces.  This collaborative IRES project between Arizona State University and University of Cyprus will engage students in the following research problems: a) How do we use imaging to detect cloud movement, predict shading and elevate efficiency? b) How can the array connections be reconfigured based on imaging, weather, and I-V data to elevate efficiency? c) How can we detect and classify panel faults in real time using machine learning and other algorithms? d) How do we extend these solar monitoring and control concepts from utility-scale solar farms to house rooftop systems?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This IRES program created significant research innovations, software, hardware, algorithms and other content in sensors and machine learning for energy and other applications. The program collaboration was with the University of  Cyprus (UCy) in Nicosia, Cyprus.  The IRES engaged a total of 20 students (2 graduate and 18 undergraduate students).  Students worked with faculty mentors from the ASU SenSIP center and from the KIOS Center of Excellence at UCy which is one of the most well known centers in the Republic of Cyprus.  

In addition to technical contributions, students were exposed to Cyprus policies and standards through UCy faculty and university officer presentations. Students presented their work in the annual Cyprus Workshop on Signal Processing and Informatics (CWSPI) in Nicosia, Cyprus.  Students also presented their research to ASU SenSIP and UCy KIOS center faculty, SenSIP industry representatives, and US Embassy (Nicosia) personnel. 

The IRES experience also included visits to cultural and historical sites in Cyprus.

Outcomes include machine learning research and training, publications, patents, student paper awards, placement in prestigious organizations and research reports co-authored by IRES participants.  Details on outcomes are listed below.

Publications: Approximately half of the participants became co-authors on conference papers. Publications include [1-11] and topics published include machine learning for energy applications, encryption, and AI for imaging and analytics

 

Patent disclosures and provisional patents of IRES participants include those listed in [12-14].  

Student Paper Awards, Accolades and Placements after IRES:  IRES sponsored students Kristen Jaskie (2020) and Salil Naik (2024) received student paper awards on publications [2] and [7] respectively.  Student Leslie Miller also received the Impact Award at ASU (2023) and she is now with the US Space Force. After the IRES experience student Niki Kyriakou [5] received admission from Johns Hopkins University. After completing the IRES program, student Max Yarter [6] is now employed at the Georgia Tech Research Institute (GTRI). The connection made through IRES for student Gabrielle Miller from Texas A&M, who was the lead author on [11], secured for her an internship at Harvard University in the summer of 2025.

 

More IRES Info including project reports, activity photos, posters, intellectual merit and broader impact statements listed in [15].

Publications Co-authored by IRES Participants (bold font)

[1]  E.  Pedersen, S. Rao, K. Jaskie, A. Spanias, C. Tepedelenlioglu, E. Kyriakides, 'PV Array Fault Detection using Radial Basis Networks', Proc. IEEE IISA, 2019 

[2] K. Jaskie, J. Martin, S. Rao, W. Barnard, P. Spanias, E. Kyriakides, Y.Tofis, L. Hadjidemetriou, M. Michael, T. Theocharides, S. Hadjistassou, and A. Spanias, 'IRES Program in Sensors and Machine Learning for Energy Systems,' Proc. IEEE IISA 2020, 2020.  (Student paper award) 

[3] J. Booth, A. Alkhateeb, A. Ewaisha, A. Spanias, 'Deep Learning Based MIMO Channel Prediction: An Initial Proof of Concept Prototype,'  IEEE Asilomar Conference, Monterey, 2020.

[4] J. Martin, K. Jaskie, Y. Tofis, A. Spanias,”  PV Array Soiling Detection using Machine Learning Fault Detection,”   Proc. IEEE IISA 2021, 2021.

[5] Glen Uehara, Jean Larson, Wendy Barnard, Michael Esposito, Filippo Posta, Maxwell Yarter, Aradhita Sharma, Niki Kyriacou, Matthew Dobson, Andreas Spanias, 'Undergraduate Research and Education in Quantum Machine Learning,'  IEEE FIE 2022, Upsala, 2022

[6] M. Yarter, G. Uehara, A. Spanias, 'Implementation and Analysis of Quantum Homomorphic Encryption,' 2022 IEEE 13th IISA, 2022. 

[7] S. Naik, N. Vaughn, A. Spanias, K. Jaskie,  'Quantum classification for synthetic aperture radar,' SPIE Defense and Commercial Sensing,” National Harbor, Maryland, 2024    Student Paper Award

[8] Miller, L., Uehara, G., and Spanias, A. (2024, July). 'Image Fusion and Quantum Machine Learning for Remote Sensing Applications.' In 2024 15th IEEE IISA, 2024.

[9] L. Miller, T. Patel, G. Uehara, S. Naik, A. Spanias, 'Quantum Machine Learning and Spectrogram Fusion for Speech Recognition,' IEEE Asilomar Conf. On Circuits, Systems and Computers, Monterey, Oct. 2024.

[10] S. Naik, G. Uehara, L. Miller, K. Jaskie,  A. Spanias, 'Quantum Positive Unlabeled Learning Algorithms with Applications to Energy,' IEEE International Workshop on Machine Learning for Signal Processing, 2024,  London, 2024.

[11] Gabrielle Miller, Phillip Konstantinov, Glen Uehara, Guillermo J. Tearneyc, Andrew Thrapp, Chistos Photiou, Costas Pitris, Andreas Spanias, 'Semantic segmentation and classification of OCT colorectal polyp images,' SPIE Photonics West,  SPIE, San Francisco,  2025.   

 

Patents Co-authored by IRES Participants (students in bold font)

[12] K. Jaskie, Joshua Martin, A. Spanias   'Systems and Methods for Photovoltaic Fault Detection using a Feedback-Enhanced Positive Unlabeled Learning Method,'  US Provisional 63/109,189, 2021.

[13] Leslie Miller, Glen Uehara, Andreas Spanias, Systems and Methods for Quantum Image Fusion Methods for Remote Sensing,' US Provisional    63/553,023, 2024

[14] A. Spanias, S. Naik, L. Miller, K. Jaskie, G. Uehara, 'Systems And Methods For Quantum Positive Unlabeled Learning Algorithms With Applications To Energy, Provisional 63/691,125, 2024.

 

IRES ASU – University of Cyprus Web Site
[15] https://sensip.engineering.asu.edu/nsf-ires-project/
